item.title: Stocks Rise on Reports Iran Wants to Restart Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Relative calm returned to global markets, with stocks climbing and oil sinking alongside gold as fears subsided that Israel’s war against Iran would escalate into a wider conflict. Equities extended gains on news reports Tehran is signaling it wants to restart talks over nuclear programs.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescuers search through the rubble at the site of an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bat Yam on June 15, 2025.

item.title: US Stocks Rebound Strengthens on Reports Iran Is Open to Talks
item.description: The rebound in US stocks picked up steam on Monday as investors started snapping up risk-on assets after reports Iran is willing to resume nuclear talks with the US and de-escalate hostilities with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: An Ultra-Orthodox Jewish man surveys the site of a heavily damaged building after an overnight Iranian missile strike in Bnei Brak, Israel, on June 16.

item.title: G-7 Works to Secure Critical Minerals in Face of China Curbs
item.description: The Group of Seven leading economies are working to shore up supplies of critical minerals as they seek to move away from reliance on China for materials used in everything from mobile phones to wind turbines.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at the Mountain Pass mine in Mountain Pass, California.

item.title: Oil Price Surge Sparks Burst of Hedging Among Shale Drillers
item.description: The surge in oil futures spurred by the initial missile attacks in the Middle East last week triggered a wave of hedging by producers seeking to lock in the higher prices, keeping some traders up late into the night.
item.dc:creator: Lucia Kassai, David Marino

media:content.media:description: A pumpjack near Crane, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Shippers Pause Offers to Mideast as Conflict Intensifies
item.description: Some oil tanker owners and managers have paused offering their vessels for Middle Eastern routes since Friday as they assess the risks from Israel’s conflict with Iran, fueling concerns over export flows from the region and sending freight rates jumping.
item.dc:creator: Serene Cheong, Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: An oil tanker.

item.title: Active ETFs Now Outnumber Passive Funds in Industry Watershed Moment
item.description: The ETF market has hit a symbolic turning point: active funds now outnumber passive ones for the first time, marking a sharp break from the industry’s index-tracking origins — even if actively managed assets still account for just a tenth of assets.
item.dc:creator: Katie Greifeld

item.title: Europe Gas Erases Gains as Fear of Wider Middle East War Eases
item.description: European natural gas erased gains on reports that Iran signaled it’s willing to de-escalate the conflict with Israel, easing concerns of a wider war in the energy-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: A gas storage site in Germany.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Wants to Talk After Israeli Airstrikes
item.description: President Donald Trump said Iran wants to talk about de-escalating the conflict with Israel. “They’d like to talk, but they should have done that before,” Trump said at the start of a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney at a Group of Seven leaders summit in Kananaskis, Alberta.

item.title: Foreign Demand for Treasuries Is Showing ‘Cracks,’ BofA Says
item.description: Central banks have been selling Treasuries since March, suggesting that they are diversifying away from dollar assets, according to Bank of America Corp.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 31, 2024. The US Treasury Department was hacked by a Chinese state-sponsored actor through a third-party software service provider, according to a letter the agency sent to Congress on Monday.

item.title: Trump Sees Trade Deal With Canada as ‘Achievable’
item.description: President Donald Trump said a trade deal between the US and Canada is achievable, but the two countries have “different concepts” on trade. “I’m a tariff person,” Trump said at the start of a meeting with Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney at a Group of Seven leaders summit in Kananaskis, Alberta.

item.title: Naval Force Sees Minor Cargo Dip Via Oil Chokepoint Hormuz
item.description: A naval coalition that seeks to keep commercial shipping safe in and around the Persian Gulf said there appears to have been a small drop in cargo traffic through the strait of Hormuz, a vital oil chokepoint, since Israel’s airstrikes on Iran on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: An Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) speed boat sails near a cargo vessel along the Persian Gulf, near the Bushehr nuclear power plant in the seaport city of Bushehr, Iran, on April 29, 2024.

item.title: Manufacturing CEO Sees a Factory Resurgence
item.description: Flex is an advanced manufacturing company that builds products for industries including cloud computing, data centers, aerospace and defense. Flex CEO Revathi Advaithi joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the trends she's seeing in US manufacturing as President Trump's tariffs reshape global trade. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nigeria’s Gasoline Retailers Warn of Dangote Refinery Monopoly
item.description: Gasoline retailers in Nigeria accused Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest person, of seeking to monopolize the sales of petroleum products in the West African nation with his mega refinery.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Pipelines at the Dangote Industries oil refinery in the Ibeju Lekki district of Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: Beef Processor Kilcoy Files for US IPO Showing Rising Profit
item.description: Kilcoy Global Foods Ltd. filed early Monday for an initial public offering in the US, to capitalize on the fast-growing appetites of both US and Asian consumers for prepared protein-based foods.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Cuts of beef are dropped into a mincer at a processing facility in Inverell, Australia.

item.title: Eaton Agrees to Buy Defense Group Ultra PCS for $1.6 Billion
item.description: Eaton Corp. agreed to buy defense and aerospace systems company Ultra Precision Control Systems from private equity firm Advent.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Kirchfeld, Ignacio Gonzalez, Swetha Gopinath

item.title: Hacksaw’s Holders Seek as Much as $355 Million in Stockholm IPO
item.description: Shareholders in Hacksaw, a developer and distributor of online betting games, plan to raise as much as 3.35 billion Swedish kronor ($355 million) in an initial public offering in Stockholm.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel

media:content.media:description: A opening bell hangs at the Nasdaq Swedish Stock Exchange during the listing ceremony for Traton SE, Volkswagen AG's truck unit, in Stockholm, Sweden, on Friday, June 28, 2019. Volkswagen raised 1.55 billion euros ($1.8 billion) selling a stake in its trucks business, but only after pricing the offer at the low end of a target range to attract investors to one of Europe’s biggest initial public offerings this year.

item.title: Solo Brands Shares Soar as Debt-Restructuring Deal Reached
item.description: Solo Brands Inc. reached a debt-restructuring deal and took the interim tag of Chief Executive Officer John Larson as the outdoor-leisure firm has struggled with years of unprofitability.
item.dc:creator: Georgia Hall

item.title: Mitsubishi Said in Advanced Talks on $8 Billion Aethon Deal
item.description: Mitsubishi Corp. is in advanced talks to buy the assets of Aethon Energy Management for close to $8 billion, people familiar with the matter said, in what would be the Japanese conglomerate’s biggest ever acquisition.
item.dc:creator: David Carnevali, Dinesh Nair, Manuel Baigorri, Ruth Liao

media:content.media:description: Signage on a Mitsubishi Motors Corp. Triton pickup truck during a media event at the company's facility in Kawasaki, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, on Thursday, Nov. 30, 2023. Mitsubishi Motor will bring back its Triton pickup truck to Japan next year after a 12-year hiatus from its home market, targeting customers in rural areas and the boom in outdoor activities like camping.

item.title: US Bonds Trim Losses as Oil Falls After Surge Toward Year’s High
item.description: US Treasuries trimmed losses as oil prices as oil prices tumbled from near five-month highs after a report Iran was seeking a de-escalation of hostilities with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie, Ruth Carson, Mary Nicola

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - Flags flutter along a bridge as a plume of heavy smoke and fire rise from an oil refinery in southern Tehran, after it was hit in an overnight Israeli strike, on June 15, 2025. Iran fired a fresh barrage of missiles at Israel, state television announced early on June 15, as the rivals exchanged fire for a third day. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Three European Startups with World-Changing Potential
item.description: Jaroslaw Kutylowski, CEO and founder of DeepL; Mati Staniszewski, co-founder of ElevenLabs; and Torsten Reil, co-founder and co-CEO of Helsing, join Bloomberg’s Amy Thomson to discuss what it takes to build a European startup with global impact. The three tech leaders analyze the latest applications of AI, the opportunities it brings, and the challenges of building trust throughout society. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Housing Isn’t Expensive for Everyone
item.description: Do you have a ZIRP-era mortgage or not?
item.dc:creator: Joe Weisenthal, Tracy Alloway

media:content.media:description: Solar panels on the roofs of homes in Tucson, Arizona, US, on Thursday, May 22, 2025. The House has passed a bill that would gut key clean-energy tax incentives, but Senate Republicans say they will make changes to the bill, including softening aggressive phaseouts of tax credits for clean electricity production. Photographer: Rebecca Noble/Bloomberg

item.title: Mali to Take Control of Key Barrick Gold Mine for Six Months
item.description: A Malian court ruled that Barrick Mining Corp.’s Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex should be placed under provisional administration for six months, handing control of one of the Canadian company’s biggest operations to state-appointed management.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Diakaridia Dembele

media:content.media:description: Dumper trucks collect rock ore from from the digging floor in a section of the Loulo-Gounkoto gold mining complex. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Boeing Progressing at Fastest Pace in Years on Air Force One
item.description: Boeing Co. said it’s made more progress in the past four to five months on the long-delayed new presidential aircraft than at any point in the last four years as it identifies ways to streamline the complex program.
item.dc:creator: Benedikt Kammel

media:content.media:description: Air Force One on the tarmac at Palm Beach International Airport.

item.title: Trump Crypto Ally Justin Sun Poised to Take Tron Public Through Reverse Merger
item.description: Justin Sun, the China-born crypto entrepreneur with ties to the Trump family who saw a federal investigation of his business interests paused earlier this year, is set to take his Tron blockchain platform public in the US through a reverse merger.
item.dc:creator: Muyao Shen

media:content.media:description: Justin Sun, founder of TRON, during the Bitcoin 2025 conference in Las Vegas, Nevada, US, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. The event will examine Bitcoin's evolving global impact with speakers from education, policy, finance, and technology. Photographer: Bridget Bennett/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Edges Lower After Report Iran Wants to Resume Talks
item.description: Gold edged lower, erasing gains made earlier in the day, as fears subsided that Israel’s war against Iran would drag in other countries.
item.dc:creator: Jason Scott, Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant arranged in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated.

item.title: Many Exporters No Longer Want Dollars, US Bank Executive Says
item.description: When Paula Comings, the head of currency sales for US Bancorp, talks to US importers, she increasingly hears the same message: Their foreign counterparties no longer want to be paid in dollars.
item.dc:creator: Carter Johnson

media:content.media:description: A worker operates a forklift to sort packaged goods destined for export, at a warehouse along the US-Mexico border in Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua state, Mexico, on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2025. US President Donald Trump agreed to delay 25% tariffs against Mexico for one month after a conversation with his counterpart Claudia Sheinbaum on Monday, a dramatic turnabout with the neighboring nations on the brink of a trade war.

item.title: UK Ethanol Maker in Last-Ditch Survival Effort on US Threat
item.description: A UK ethanol producer that has warned of the risk to its business from tariff-free US imports said it is almost too late to save its output.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Graham

item.title: Sir Nick Clegg on Democracy and Digital Power
item.description: Sir Nick Clegg, outgoing President of Global Affairs at Meta and former UK Deputy Prime Minister, speaks with Bloomberg’s Lizzy Burden about the intersection of politics and technology. He discusses how he helped make social media more accountable and explores the future impact of AI on Meta. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Launches Self-Branded Mobile Phone Service
item.description: President Donald Trump’s family is getting into the mobile phone business with a Trump-branded service that will rely on pre-existing wireless networks and hardware that is “made in America.” Caroline Hyde reports on “Bloomberg Open Interest.”

item.title: Israel Strikes Continue Amid Reports Iran Keen to De-Escalate
item.description: Israel and Iran exchanged fire for the fourth consecutive day on Monday, stoking fears of an all-out war with the potential to drag in others in the oil-rich region and force the US into a more hands-on stance.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei in 2024.
